EVENT_NARRATIVE: The daily high temperature record of 98 degrees was tied at Modesto Airport. The previous record was set in 2001.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the region brought unseasonably warm temperatures to the northern San Joaquin Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Shasta County woman died of heat stroke on July 4th in her home in Round Mountain, according to the forensic pathologist at the Shasta County coroner's office.  The high temperature at Redding Airport was 113 degrees, which fell one degree short of the record of 114 degrees for the date, which was set in 1991.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the western United States brought record heat to Northern California on July 4 and 5th.

Strong high pressure aloft, large scale subsidence, and very warm 850 mb temperatures caused a significant heat wave in the mountains and in the Coachella Valley between the 4th and 6th of July. High temperatures were generally around 115 degrees in the lower deserts, 105 degrees in the mountains between 3-5k ft, 100 degrees between 5-6k ft, and 95 degrees between 6-7k ft. Big Bear Lake, at an elevation of 6760 ft, tied their all-time record high with a temperature of 94 degrees. At an elevation of 4240 ft, Julian came within 2 degrees of their all-time record high with a temperature of 107 degrees. Other notable high temperatures in the mountains include 103 degrees at Cuyamaca, 100 degrees at Idyllwild, 97 degrees at Palomar, 95 degrees at Lake Arrowhead, and 94 degrees at Mount Laguna. In the Coachella Valley, Ocotillo Wells reached 119 degrees, Palm Springs and Indio reached 116 degrees, and Anza Borrego Park reached 115 degrees.||Due to an extremely strong marine layer inversion in excess of 15 degrees celcius at times, most valley and coastal cities west of the mountains were unaffetced by the heat wave. As a result, there was not a lot of media coverage regarding the impacts of this heat wave. Given that this heat wave occurred during the week of the July 4th holiday, it is likely that there were a number of people who fell ill to the heat, however this number is unknown.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: New daily high temperature records were set today at the Stockton Airport and Modesto Airport sites.  ||- At Stockton Airport...the temperature reached 109 degrees, which broke the old record of 106 degrees set in 1968.||- At Modesto Airport...the temperature reached 110 degrees, which broke the old record of 107 degrees set in 1940.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the western United States brought record heat to Northern California on July 4 and 5th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: New daily high temperature records were set today at the Downtown Sacramento and the Sacramento Executive Airport sites.  ||- At Downtown Sacramento...the temperature reached 108 degrees, which broke the old record of 107 degrees set in 1931.||- At Sacramento Executive Airport...the temperature reached 107 degrees, which broke the old record of 105 degrees set in 1968.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the western United States brought record heat to Northern California on July 4 and 5th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures were very hot across the northern Sacramento Valley today and came close to reaching the daily high temperature records at the Redding Airport and Red Bluff Airport observation sites.  ||- At Redding Airport...the temperature reached 112 degrees, just shy of the old city record of 113 degrees set in 1984.||- At Red Bluff Airport...the temperature reached 111 degrees, just shy of the old record of 112 degrees set in 1984.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the western United States brought record heat to Northern California on July 4 and 5th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The combination of above normal temperatures and relative humidity produced excessive heat across the San Fernando and San Gabriel Valleys with heat index values between 105 and 112 reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: From the 29th through the 31st, strong high pressure built over the southwest United States. With this pattern, above normal temperatures developed across the mountains and valleys of Southern California. An influx of monsoonal moisture from northern Mexico increased the relative humidity across the area. The combination of very hot temperatures and increased relative humidity produce heat index values between 105 and 112 degrees. The excessive heat resulted in numerous heat-related injuries and deaths. The heat wave extended into the first few days of September.

Strong high pressure caused excessively hot temperatures to develop over the southern San Joaquin Valley during the end of August, 2007.  Energy officials urged valley residents to conserve energy during this time period, between the 30th and 31st.  The temperature at Meadows Field in Bakersfield hit 104 degrees on the 30th and 106 degrees on the 31st.  The nighttime heat index on the night of the 30th remained at or above 82 degrees.  These temperatures met critical criteria for heat advisory conditions in the San Joaquin Valley.

Strong high pressure and easterly flow brought hot, humid weather to much of Southern California. Temperatures exceeded 95 along the coast and in the mountains, 105 in the Orange and San Diego County valleys, 110 in the Inland Empire and high deserts, and 115 in the lower deserts. Humidity levels were quite high for the region, especially in the lower deserts where periodic gulf surges would raise the dewpoint into the 70s. At least 6 people died of heat related causes within the CWA, however the actual number of deaths is probably higher than indicated.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The combination of above normal temperatures and relative humidity produced excessive heat conditions across the lower valleys of Los Angeles county. Heat index values between 105 and 112 were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The heat wave which started at the end of August continued into the first few days of September. The combination of above normal temperatures and relative humidity continued to produce excessive heat conditions across sections of Southern California. At the end of the heat wave, 18 heat-related deaths were reported across Los Angeles county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at Van Nuys Airport reported a high temperature of 109 degrees with a heat index of 105 degrees.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of strong high pressure centered over Arizona and weak offshore flow generated extreme heat conditions across Central and Southern California. Across many sections of the area, afternoon temperatures climbed to between 100 and 114 degrees which set numerous high temperature records. The extreme heat resulted in several power outages due to excessive electrical use.

An extreme heat event developed on July 8 across Interior Central CA as a strong ridge of high pressure setup across the region. This weather pattern promoted progressively increasing temperatures for several days with excessive heat warning criteria met in some locations beginning the night of July 8, and continuing in most locations through July 11.  Maximum temperatures on the 9th and 10th were generally between 105-112 degrees.  Unusually humid conditions resulted in heat index values of 110 degrees or higher in many locations.  Nighttime relief was very limited, especially in cities, where minimum heat index values failed to drop below 80 degrees.  In addition, very poor air quality occurred coincident with the heat event due to wildfires across CA.  The San Joaquin Valley Air Pollution Control District, in cooperation with NWS Hanford, issued several Air Quality Alerts, Health Advisories, and other air quality statements, in response to the poor air quality.  NWS Hanford has a well-developed agreement to assist the Air District with air quality information dissemination. ||Temperature records have been broken at several locations.  The low temperature at Bakersfield on July 10th was 86 degrees. This breaks the record highest minimum temperature at Bakersfield for the date of 82 degrees, set in 2002.  The low temperature at Fresno on July 10th was 82 degrees. This breaks the record for the highest minimum temperature at Fresno for the date of 80 degrees, set in 1896.  The low temperature at Bakersfield on July 9th was 84 degrees. This was 7 degrees warmer than the record high minimum temperature at Bakersfield for the date of 77 degrees, set in 1975.  The low temperature at Fresno on July 9th was 81 degrees. This was 2 degrees warmer than the record high minimum temperature at Fresno for the date of 79 degrees, set in 1896.||Two fatalities occurred during this extreme heat event. Both fatalities were in Kern County near Maricopa. The victims were both farm workers working during the heat event. The first fatality occurred of a 42 year old male vineyard worker in Kern County.  He was found in his truck along a highway and vineyard. The second fatality was a man of unknown age, also working in the vineyard near Maricopa. ||The combination of very hot weather of very poor air quality created a situation very dangerous for those individuals sensitive to poor conditions, such as the elderly, young, and those with chronic health problems.||Kings County Government reported extensive poultry losses on July 10, dollar estimates were unavailable.  An estimated 150 tons of dead poultry came into a local rendering plant.  Kings County declared a local state of emergency.

This was 2 degrees warmer than the record high minimum temperature at Fresno for the date of 79 degrees, set in 1896.||Two fatalities occurred during this extreme heat event. Both fatalities were in Kern County near Maricopa. The victims were both farm workers working during the heat event. The first fatality occurred of a 42 year old male vineyard worker in Kern County.  He was found in his truck along a highway and vineyard. The second fatality was a man of unknown age, also working in the vineyard near Maricopa. ||The combination of very hot weather of very poor air quality created a situation very dangerous for those individuals sensitive to poor conditions, such as the elderly, young, and those with chronic health problems.||Kings County Government reported extensive poultry losses on July 10, dollar estimates were unavailable.  An estimated 150 tons of dead poultry came into a local rendering plant.  Kings County declared a local state of emergency.

An extreme heat event developed on July 8 across Interior Central CA as a strong ridge of high pressure setup across the region. This weather pattern promoted progressively increasing temperatures for several days with excessive heat warning criteria met in some locations beginning the night of July 8, and continuing in most locations through July 11.  Maximum temperatures on the 9th and 10th were generally between 105-112 degrees.  Unusually humid conditions resulted in heat index values of 110 degrees or higher in many locations.  Nighttime relief was very limited, especially in cities, where minimum heat index values failed to drop below 80 degrees.  In addition, very poor air quality occurred coincident with the heat event due to wildfires across CA.  The San Joaquin Valley Air Pollution Control District, in cooperation with NWS Hanford, issued several Air Quality Alerts, Health Advisories, and other air quality statements, in response to the poor air quality.  NWS Hanford has a well-developed agreement to assist the Air District with air quality information dissemination. ||Temperature records have been broken at several locations.  The low temperature at Bakersfield on July 10th was 86 degrees. This breaks the record highest minimum temperature at Bakersfield for the date of 82 degrees, set in 2002. The low temperature at Fresno on July 9th was 81 degrees.
